awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research in Gauge Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding of the structure of the four-dimensional universe in which we live is a key topic of investigation in modern mathematics and physics. Gauge theory is a crucial tool for the study of the mathematical structures that provide the context for standard models of the physical world. The research supported by this project will develop new mathematical tools and theories that will help test such models and advance our understanding of four-dimensional spaces. A key mathematical idea is the interaction between three-dimensional theories known as Floer theories and the study of invariants of four-dimensional spaces. In addition the project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.

This project will develop and extend invariants including abelian gauge theoretic models, cobordism invariants arising from the critical values of Morse like functions such as Daemi's Gamma invariant, equivariant extensions such as equivariant singular instanton knot homology, and new parameterized invariants that combine Konno adjunction-style complexes with homotopy invariants of families. It will also translate structures uncovered in some gauge theory packages to other packages, for example translating L-space notions from Heegaard Floer theory to analogues in the instanton case, or equivariant structures from the Seiberg-Witten Floer theory to the Heegaard Floer theory. Topological applications will include new insights into knot concordance, homology cobordism, diffeomorphism groups of 4-manifolds, and SU(2) representations of 3-manifold groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A manifold is a space that, on a small scale, looks like our everyday world, but after zooming out, it can have interesting shapes. For instance, consider living in a two-dimensional world where movement is restricted to forward, backward, left, or right. If this world were confined to the surface of a sphere, such as the Earth, the immediate surroundings would feel flat—just as standing in an open field appears flat to us. However, on a global scale, one would observe that the surface loops back on itself and has no edges. Now, imagine instead that this two-dimensional world is the surface of a doughnut (a torus). In this case, traveling far enough in one direction could return one to the starting point, but in a manner different from the sphere. These examples illustrate just two of the many possible two-dimensional spaces.

In three dimensions, the possibilities become even richer and more interesting. Just as two-dimensional spaces can take the form of a sphere or a torus, three-dimensional manifolds can have many different shapes and structures, which are usually difficult to visualize. While such spaces seem ordinary and familiar when viewed locally, they might have interesting unexpected global properties. Knots, in the mathematical sense, are loops of string tangled in a 3-dimensional space, much like the knots one might tie in a piece of rope, but with one key difference: the ends are connected, forming a closed loop. One can imagine taking a loop of string, weaving it through itself in various ways, and then connecting the ends. This is what mathematicians define as a knot. Studying the shapes and properties of 3-dimensional manifolds and the knots within them is a key focus in low-dimensional topology. This area of research explores how spaces are connected and how they can be transformed without cutting or tearing. The PI uses geometric methods to develop new tools and answer questions about the topology of 3-dimensional spaces and their intricate relationships to knots.

Connections on principal bundles are among the key geometrical objects appearing in the PI's work. A connection on a principal bundle is a tool that helps us understand how to compare directions as we move through a curved space. It’s like having a consistent rule for how to align a compass at every point on a surface or in space, even when the space itself has twists and turns. Recently, Christopher Scaduto and the PI defined a suite of knot invariants, collectively referred to as equivariant singular instanton theory, using connections on 3-dimensional spaces that are singular along knots. They also used this construction to produce lower bounds for several improtant numerical invariants of knots (e.g. 4-dimensional genus and unknotting number). This allows them to address a conjecture of Livingston and answer a question of Kronheimer and Mrowka. In another work, the Pi and his collaborators propose some connections among some of the numerical invariants of knots from gauge theory. Beside providing some pieces of evidence toward this proposal, they give several topological applications including a partial answer to a conjecture of Hedden and Pinzón-Caicedo.

Instanton Floer theory also provides a family of 3-manifold invariants. In a recent work, the PI studies a refinement of instanton Floer homology of 3-manifolds by an energy filtration and uses this to define numerical invariants of 3-manfiolds which are unchanged with respect to the homology cobordism relation. Such invariants have already proven useful in several directions. For instance, the PI and his collaborators used these numerical invariants to study handle decomposition complexity of 4-manifolds, showing that there are integer homology spheres that bound homology 4-balls, but any such bounding four-manifold must be built out of many handles. Similar constructions are employed in the PI's collaborative projects to make progress toward the cosmetic surgery conjecture and disproving a conjecture of Etnyre, Min, and Mukherjee, which states that any 3-manifold admits an embedding into a symplectic 4-manifold.

Applications of instanton Floer theory to the study of 3-manifolds and knots have been mostly limited to the case that one uses connections on SU(2)-bundles. The PI and his collaborators gave applications of instanton Floer homology where Lie groups of higher ranks are used. For instance, they employed SU(3) instanton homology to address N=3 version of a conjecture proposed by Xie and the PI, which can be regraded as a generalozation of the Smith Conjecture about diffeomorphism of the 3-sphere.

The PI has disseminated his work by giving talks at departmental colloquia, conferences and specialized seminars. During the support of this grant, he also organized a research program for undergraduates (Freiwald Scholars Program) at Washington University.
